reviewText: Martin Clunes is one of my favorite British actors, and I have enjoyed many of his movies and TV series.  I had watched the first 2 seasons on "William and Mary" several years ago, and when I heard that all 3 seasons were available together, I had to have them.  I totally enjoyed getting reacquainted with "William" (Clunes) and "Mary" (Julie Graham) and their blended family.  A great series!

reviewText: Not a King/Queen but Undertaker /Midwife duo widens the gap for wit and charm. Martin Clunes (Doc Martin) leads a dynamic on/off relationship similar to Doc Martin and his teacher friend. This time she's a midwife (Cheryl Campbell -Bletchley Circle). Plot is rife with comic situations amid two tangoing careers. Tenderness too. Both have 2 teenagers and ringing phones; always on-call. "William & Mary" brings a layered plot balance between stiffs & babies. Laughs against walls of high emotion, in every episode. Use `pause' when laughing/weeping or you'll miss something in the fast action.Highly recommended. Loved each episode. Fell in love with this family.SDH SUBTITLES provided for all 3 seasons, 18 episodes of 48 min.Apology for short episode synopsis; too many & all fully packed with subplots.Series 1 Ep 1: 1st date with Mary a disaster-a funny one.1-2: Mary's mum Molly (Cheryl Campbell) interferes with W&M;'s next step.1-3: W&M;'s explosive relationship filters into home & work.1-4: Life strains hamper W&M; bliss.1-5: Wm looses his mom; Mary's old flame visits.1-6: Funeral home & Mary's ex both on the block.2-1: Nothing seems to dampen engagement bliss...till Molly--.2-2: Search for new funeral parlor leads to home shopping.2-3: W&M; both find new career challenges.2-4: More downs than ups in pre-nuptial days, but funny. Guest Star (G*) Miranda Hart (Call the Midwife)2-5: Tragedy a week before `I do.' G* Annette Crosbie (Little Dorrit); Jeff Rawle.2-6: New house proves not a happy home. Wedding woes.3-1: Baby/toddler is just one of new stressors for W&M.; G* Tim Woodward (Wings)3-2: W&M; deprived seriously desired 1-ON-1 time.3-3: W&M; both find themselves with flirtation from an un-significant other. G* Michael Fassbender3-4: W&M; son's safety threatened by gang. London's weirdest funeral. G* Miles Anderson3-5: Will Molly's health improve W&M;'s relationship? G* Clare Holman (Insp. Lewis)3-6: New home for the series finale. Good wrapup. Fun show.
summary: 21st century family chaos drama fast pace misadventure

reviewText: Fans of Martin Clunes will be over the moon about the release of WILLIAM & MARY. Clunes is a dynamic actor of considerable range, capable of playing cold-hearted characters (like Doc Martin) and the guy you’d like to have as your next door neighbour, (as in this show). The premise of the series gives Clunes the opportunity to do everything he does well: play subtle comedy, be poignant, be a staunch representative of middle-class values, all the while displaying remarkable sensitivity and likeability.Julie Graham as Mary is also exceptionally good, but her character’s occasional instability, while dramatically interesting, is a bit hard to believe. Nonetheless the chemistry between these two actors is wonderful to behold. From the bonus interview it is clear they are good friends, having known each other and worked together (Dirty Tricks, also available from Acorn Media).Their central relationship is at the heart of the series, though ironically it proves to be lacking in one important aspect: there is no moral centre to their relationship. While other characters marry and find their own stability through trial and commitment, William and Mary remain in a curious state of relationship limbo. Will they be fine until Mary has her next emotional crisis?Similarly, the bed hopping, drug use and teenage sexual encounters depicted are never commented upon. Are William and Mary blind to these goings on, or are they reflecting a “new morality”?Despite this flaw in an otherwise brilliant show, WILLIAM & MARY will satisfy viewers interested in romance and (in Clunes’ case) very appealing characters. The writing, apart from the occasionally absent parenting skills, is remarkable and the pacing and editing of the show really conveys the semi-madness of living in William and Mary’s household. Secondary characters almost steal the show away from the leads, particularly Cheryl Campbell as Mary’s free-spirited mother and her boyfriend Rick, brilliantly played by Michael Begley. Mention must also be made of Paterson Joseph who plays the father to Mary’s two children. His Reuben manages the difficult task of being repulsive to begin with but ultimately someone you root for. These are classic examples of character development and one of the strongest aspects of the series.Some of the guest stars are a revelation as well, including the brilliant Michael Fassbender and a little-know character actor named Peter MacQueen, whose comic brilliance is used to great effect. Why this outstanding actor has not had a more prominent career is anyone’s guess. The injustices of the profession, I suppose.WILLIAM & MARY is highly satisfying entertainment. Try not to be put off by a rather weak conclusion. There is much to savour and enjoy here.
summary: Fans of Martin Clunes will love it.

reviewText: I didn't know anything about this series, but because I really enjoy Martin Clunes as Doc Martin and  loved Julie Graham in The Bone Kickers and Survivors, I thought I'd give it a try.  I am so glad I did!  This is a very good, very real feeling story in spite of being the portrayal of a romance between a midwife and an undertaker.  This unusual pairing does create some interesting problems, especially in the early days as two very busy people try to make time for each other.  The dating agency they both have signed with has encouraged William to hide his profession.  That is a less than promising beginning for a new relationship, as Mary discovers what he does unexpectedly.  They manage to work it out, but not without some bumps in the smooth flow of their dating. I found myself laughing out loud at small things that seemed so on target and realistic, such as finding a good time in their schedules to have a date, and coming up with Monday morning.  Any time William interacts with his daughters it is a gem.....a real dad and real children, no bumbling stupid clueless parent, William may not know everything, but he does parent well, and the girls are not precocious know-it-alls, but young girls, one part sweetness and one part self-absorbed adolescents.  Mary's boys are more tuned in on their mom's life, but they too seem to mostly exist in that world apart that teenagers inhabit, and Mary is struggling to keep them from drifting away from studies and pursuit of goals.  Life for these characters is not without issues and problems, but underneath everything is the care and love William and Mary have for each other, their families and their clients.
summary: Good Series!  Modern yet Timeless Storytelling with Characters you will Love.

reviewText: We watched only the first episode.  That was enough.  Perhaps if we had not seen Doc Martin, this would have been more acceptable.  However, too much emphasis is placed on revealing as much of women's private parts as possible.  The story line is weak, perhaps that is why more skin is revealed.  For instance, his daughter keeps asking to spent the night at a friend's house and he says no.  There is no argument, just good natured acceptance.  Really, what family is like that?  Of course, the daughter is granted such permission after the father gets lucky.  The story lines are not even that funny.  Maybe I should have given it two stars.
summary: A real downer after Doc Martin

reviewText: I found it very puzzling that William wanted anything to do with Mary - she's an unlikeable character and doesn't treat him very well. That being said, I think it's a lack of any deep development of Mary's character that made me feel this way. I like both of these actors very much, so I was disappointed.

reviewText: WILLIAM AND MARY, a British TV series that might be described as a comedy/romance/drama now returns to DVD in a six DVD box set.  It was made by Granada/ITV, and was broadcast on British television from 2003-2005; in the United States it has been broadcast on public television channels.  It stars Martin Clunes (DOC MARTIN, SHAKESPEARE IN LOVE) as undertaker William Shawcross. Julie Graham (THE BLETCHLEY CIRCLE, THE BILL, BONE KICKERS; she's appeared in DOC MARTIN too) costars as midwife Mary Gilchrist.  The box set included all three series of this deftly-written, solidly-acted entertainment, plus a bonus 40-minute cast interview segment.  It's also available by various streaming services.  The BAFTA-nominated show consists of 18 episodes, running 14  hours, and is meant for mature audiences.  And, thank you Acorn/RLJ Entertainment, there are available subtitles, as the Scottish-born Graham never goes anywhere without her brogue.  And the greatly talented Cheryl Campbell, (PENNIES FROM HEAVEN, TESTAMENT OF YOUTH, CHARIOTS OF FIRE), who plays Mary's Scottish mother Molly, is certainly no slouch at the brogue, which I imagine she comes by honestly. Guest stars include Oscar-nominated Michael Fassbender (12 YEARS A SLAVE), the Scottish-born Annette Crosbie, (ONE FOOT IN THE GRAVE, DOCTOR WHO); Saskia Wickham, Tim Woodward, and Clare Holman.The London-set series, penned by actor/writer Mick Ford, tells the story of the growing, improbable relationship of Shawcross and Graham, both single parents, he of two girls, she of two boys.  Each protagonist has been looking for love, but in all the wrong places.  He generally works with the very dead; most women are put off by his occupation.  She's a harried, no-nonsense midwife, who works with birthing mothers and their nervous husbands.  They are brought together by a local dating service that advises him to lie about his job: he falls for her above all their candidates, for her "laughing eyes." She likes him too, until she discovers his work. She brings people into the world.  He ushers them out.  The demands of their unpredictable jobs and families will keep their relationship complicated.With thanks to Acorn/RLJ, the episodes are:Disc 1 (Series 1)EPISODE ONEWilliam Shawcross's search for love stops when he sees Mary Gilcrest. But their first date is a disaster as their jobs interfere.EPISODE TWOWilliam believes his relationship with Mary is over before it is even begun, but she's simply preoccupied with a truant teenager and her meddling mother, Molly, who's got "fix up" plans of her own.EPISODE THREEWilliam and Mary's first night of passion is compromised  when one of his daughters goes missing. Mary gets suspended for trying to save a baby's life; William's latest memorial service is literally explosive.Disc 2 (Series 1)EPISODE FOURWilliam is working overtime handling the tragic deaths of three teenagers. Mary has kicked Molly out for her meddling; she sets back William's hopes when she tells him to slow down.EPISODE FIVEThe death of William's mother throws him into a tailspin. Meanwhile, Mary deals with a troubled pregnant teenager.  Her unreliable ex-husband, thought to be in America, turns up on her doorstep.EPISODE SIXThe awkward encounter with Mary's ex-husband, Reuben, persuades William to end his relationship with Mary and sell the business. But when she learns of his plans, she makes a dramatic plea to start over.Disc 3 (Series 2)EPISODE ONEWilliam and Mary are engaged, and even a troubling legal development can't dampen the mood.  Molly  marries Rick, the younger suitor she wanted for Mary.EPISODE TWOWilliam's new funeral home is a go. He surprises Mary with a fixer-upper dream house;  she has a surprise, too: she's pregnant.EPISODE THREEMary explores her options as an independent midwife. Meanwhile, funeral preparations for a notorious criminal put everyone in danger.Disc 4 (Series 2)EPISODE FOURMary needs to take a break from her pesky private clients and the chaos at the new house. But William fears they're headed for financial ruin.EPISODE FIVEWilliam conducts one of the oddest funerals ever. Mary is overwhelmed by a patient's tragedy, which may affect her wedding plans.EPISODE SIXThe wedding day is finally here, but it's overshadowed by Reuben's bombshell. Mary runs off; William frantically searches for her.Disc 5 (Series 3)EPISODE ONEBaby Thomas has joyfully turned the house upside down. But the family's happiness is tempered when Molly confronts a health crisis.EPISODE TWOWilliam and Mary are desperate for some alone time, but their plans are continually thwarted by college interviews, babies in need, and a suspicious death.EPISODE THREEAfter a difficult birth, Mary is rudely propositioned by the new father, played by Fassbender. Meanwhile, William must fend off the advances of a flirtatious female lawyer.Disc 6 (Series 3)EPISODE FOURMary is furious that she's been kept in the dark about her son Terence's feud with a local gang. When William suggests the boy leave town for his safety, she begins to freeze him out.EPISODE FIVEBetween Terence's leaving and Molly's cancer battle, Mary remains frosty towards William--and tempted by a new acquaintance. But when Molly takes a turn for the worse, Mary realizes what she has with William.EPISODE SIXSome joyous news inspires William to look for a new home that will allow Terence to return. At the celebration, he and Mary realize that their dreams are coming true.The dramedy  is largely filmed in the lovely London precincts of Hampstead, and Hampstead Heath.  Thanks to its makers, the screen is always plentifully populated with people, houses, cars, in the best British TV tradition.  It's funny and moving;  gives us a charming middle-aged romance between reasonably attractive, non-anorexic adults with responsibilities, no blood and guts, car chases, or nudity. And most unusually, we really get to see quite a bit of the pair at their work,  get a good idea of what it entails.  It sometimes got a  little too happy family for me, with love being too widely spread around, what with, seemingly, always 15 people about.  But they are always interacting, tuned into each other, eating together without benefit of electronic toys. Just goes to prove that love, once found, is a force that can't be denied.  Gotta say, if you love DOC MARTIN, you'll love this.
summary: Looking for Love in All the Wrong Places
